population_specificity: Adults with coronary artery disease (CAD) and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and its associated cardiovascular risks.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP should be offered to patients with severe OSA, while oral appliances are an alternative for mild to moderate cases or CPAP-intolerant patients. Follow-up testing is recommended to assess treatment effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with OSA, particularly those with cardiovascular conditions such as hypertension, heart failure, coronary artery disease, and atrial fibrillation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP was superior to HFNC in reducing respiratory events (lower AHI) and improving sleep efficiency. HFNC improved AHI but did not enhance sleep quality.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (AHI > 5 events/h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of BiPAP versus CPAP in preterm infants with RDS after INSURE treatment, focusing on reintubation rates and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in reintubation rates between CPAP and BiPAP groups, but BiPAP resulted in shorter durations of PAP therapy and oxygen supplementation. No differences were observed in BPD, NEC, ROP, or lung function at one year.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with birth weight <1500 g and respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) post-INSURE treatment.
study_duration: Varied (CPAP group: 15.3 days, BiPAP group: 12.6 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel device enabling selective lobe ventilation and recruitment, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) for lower lobes, to address lung heterogeneity and improve ventilation in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: The study reports initial testing of a device that allows selective lobe ventilation and recruitment, including CPAP for lower lobes, showing potential benefits in customizing ventilation parameters and preventing ventilator-induced lung injury. Further research is needed to confirm clinical efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (initial in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo testing).

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of aerosolised surfactant (SF-RI 1) delivered via nCPAP and a breath synchronisation device (AeroFact) in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
results_summary: The study found no safety issues with the AeroFact system. In part 2, 29% of treated infants met failure criteria compared to 48% of historical controls, showing a trend toward reduced failure rates (p=0.10).
population_specificity: Preterm infants (26-30 weeks gestation) with RDS requiring nCPAP.
effective_dosage: Part 1: single dose of 216 mg/kg; Part 2: up to four doses of aerosolised surfactant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a new respiratory support system with low imposed work of breathing and short binasal prongs reduces delivery room intubations or death compared to a standard T-piece system with a face mask in preterm infants.
results_summary: The new respiratory support system significantly reduced delivery room intubation or death within 30 minutes of birth (33.1% vs. 45.1% with standard care), with an adjusted odds ratio of 0.53 (95% CI, 0.30-0.94; P = .03). No significant differences were observed in secondary outcomes or safety variables.
population_specificity: Extremely preterm infants (mean gestational age 25.9 weeks) in neonatal intensive care units across 5 European countries.
effective_dosage: Continuous positive airway pressure for 10 to 30 minutes, with positive pressure ventilation if needed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether sacubitril-valsartan (SV) impacts sleep apnoea (SA) in patients with chronic heart failure and reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: The study found that SV treatment for 3 months was associated with a significant decrease in the Apnoea-Hypopnoea Index (AHI), supporting guideline recommendations to optimize HFrEF treatment in patients with central SA. A potential positive airway pressure-sparing effect was noted but requires further investigation.
population_specificity: Ambulatory HFrEF patients who remained symptomatic despite optimal treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and the effects of CPAP treatment on endothelial function, cardiovascular risk, and platelet/erythrocyte activity.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP treatment improves endothelial function and may reduce cardiovascular risk in comorbidities like diabetes, atherosclerosis, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. It also highlighted OSA's role in promoting oxidative stress, inflammation, and altered blood component function, increasing stroke risk.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and associated comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, atherosclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neonatal respiratory morbidity, including the use of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP), differs by race in late preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that late preterm respiratory morbidity was similar between racial groups, with no significant differences in the primary outcome after adjusting for confounders. CPAP use was part of the composite outcome, but the study did not isolate its individual efficacy.
population_specificity: Late preterm infants (34+0 to 36+6 weeks gestation) born to women at high risk for late preterm delivery.
study_duration: Outcomes assessed within the first 72 hours after birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze mortality and intubation rates in COVID-19 patients treated with NIV or CPAP to assess their efficacy and safety.
results_summary: CPAP and NIV were frequently used but associated with high mortality (35.1% for NIV vs. 22.2% for CPAP). Non-invasive respiratory support failed in 47.7% of patients, with 26.5% intubated and 40.9% dying.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with acute respiratory failure (4776 patients, 66% males, 46% with hypertension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) as the primary treatment for Obstructive Sleep Apnoea/Hypopnoea Syndrome (OSAHS), particularly in obese patients.
results_summary: CPAP remains the treatment of choice for most OSAHS patients, effectively addressing upper airway obstruction during sleep. The study highlights its use alongside weight reduction and other interventions like mandibular advancement devices and surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnoea/Hypopnoea Syndrome (OSAHS), particularly those with central obesity.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects and safety of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for initial respiratory management of bronchiolitis in children.
results_summary: CPAP reduced hospital length of stay, respiratory rate, PaCO2, heart rate, and mechanical ventilation while increasing PaO2, but did not improve SpO2 or pH. Compared to high-flow nasal cannula, CPAP reduced treatment failure but did not decrease PICU length of stay, intubation incidence, respiratory rate, or Modified Woods Clinical Asthma Score.
population_specificity: Children with bronchiolitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of CPAP in managing postoperative hypoxemia compared to other oxygen therapies.
results_summary: The abstract suggests CPAP is discussed as a viable option for postoperative hypoxemia management, but specific efficacy results are not detailed. The recommendations are based on available evidence, implying some level of effectiveness.
population_specificity: Postoperative patients with hypoxemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine factors associated with mortality in critically ill African COVID-19 patients, including the impact of respiratory support interventions like Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP).
results_summary: CPAP was independently associated with higher mortality (odds ratio 3.93; 2.13-7.26), suggesting it was less effective or potentially harmful in this critically ill population compared to other interventions. The study did not explore CPAP's efficacy in improving patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Critically ill African adults (aged 18+) with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 admitted to intensive or high-care units across 64 hospitals in ten African countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) as primary respiratory support in preterm infants.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that HFNC had a higher risk of treatment failure compared to CPAP (RR=1.34), but no difference in intubation rates and a lower rate of nasal trauma. The study suggests HFNC could be used as primary respiratory support in preterm infants despite the higher failure risk.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the link between sleep disordered breathing (SDB) and stroke and assess the potential benefits of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in reducing stroke risk and improving neurological outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP treatment for SDB may reduce stroke risk and improve neurological outcomes post-stroke, suggesting early intervention is beneficial. SDB is an independent risk factor for stroke, and CPAP may mitigate associated risks like intermittent hypoxemia and systemic inflammation.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with sleep disordered breathing (SDB).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of CPAP therapy on 24-hour intraocular pressure (IOP) patterns in patients with severe obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS).
results_summary: Most patients with severe OSAS exhibited nocturnal IOP peaks, and CPAP therapy was associated with an additional increase in IOP during the initial phase of nocturnal acrophase. Significant differences were observed at specific time intervals (20, 25, 30, and 55 minutes) after CPAP initiation.
population_specificity: 22 newly diagnosed patients with severe OSAS.
study_duration: Two 24-hour monitoring sessions (before and after CPAP initiation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the top 100 influential manuscripts on obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and analyze their characteristics, including the role of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in treatment and outcomes.
results_summary: The most cited manuscript (Marin, J.M et al., Lancet 2005) analyzed long-term cardiovascular outcomes in men with OSA, comparing those with and without CPAP treatment. The study found that treatments, including CPAP, were a prevalent subject among the top 100 influential manuscripts, indicating its significance in OSA management.
population_specificity: Men with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if home-based auto-titrating CPAP (APAP) initiation with telemonitoring was non-inferior to standard in-lab management for compliance and quality of life in obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) patients.
results_summary: Home-based APAP initiation with telemonitoring was feasible and showed non-inferiority to standard in-lab management in therapy compliance, with significantly faster access to therapy (7.6 vs. 46.1 days). The pre-specified non-inferiority margin of 0.3 h/day was not met, but significance was achieved with a 0.5 h/day margin.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) documented by polygraphy (PG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the global heterogeneity in the use and outcomes of respiratory support methods, including CPAP, for COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: CPAP was used in 2% of patients overall, with specific mortality rates for CPAP/NIV reported at 29%. The study found that CPAP and NIV were less frequently applied compared to IMV, and data on their outcomes were often under-reported.
population_specificity: 287,359 COVID-19 patients (57.5% male, mean age 64 years) from 17 countries, with 33.3% hospitalized in ICUs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPAP treatment affects urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) in subjects with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that CPAP therapy significantly reduced UACR in subjects with OSA (SMD = 0.415, p = 0.037). Subgroup analyses showed the effect was consistent regardless of sample size, BMI, age, or AHI.
population_specificity: Subjects with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of high-flow humidified oxygen (HFHO) versus continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in improving oxygenation while maintaining nonventilated lung collapse during one-lung ventilation.
results_summary: Both CPAP and HFHO increased arterial oxygen levels, but the improvements were not statistically significant. CPAP worsened surgical conditions in half the patients, while HFHO either improved or had no effect on lung deflation.
population_specificity: 28 patients undergoing elective thoracotomy with one-lung ventilation using a double-lumen endobronchial tube.
study_duration: 20 minutes per intervention with a 20-minute recovery interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate CPAP adherence and its association with blood pressure and pulse rate changes in patients with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) and hypertension.
results_summary: CPAP adherence was associated with blood pressure lowering and pulse rate slowing effects, particularly with higher CPAP frequency. Non-adherence was defined as CPAP use for <5 days/week or <4 hours/night.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) and hypertension.
effective_dosage: CPAP frequency per week and time per night (non-adherence defined as <5 days/week or <4 hours/night).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treating sleep apnoea with CPAP slows the progression of kidney failure in patients with chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: The study primarily focused on recruitment challenges rather than CPAP's effects, noting that only 57 out of 1,665 eligible patients were randomized due to various barriers. No results on CPAP's impact on kidney function were reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and sleep apnoea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of surfactant administration via thin catheter versus endotracheal tube or continuation of non-invasive respiratory support (CPAP) in preterm infants with or at risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
results_summary: Surfactant administration via thin catheter significantly reduced the risk of death or bronchopulmonary dysplasia, decreased the need for intubation within 72 hours, and lowered the incidence of severe complications compared to endotracheal tube administration. The procedure showed similar adverse effect rates to endotracheal tube administration.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (<37 weeks' gestation) with or at risk of RDS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the cognitive effects of untreated OSA and assess the benefits of CPAP treatment across cognitive domains.
results_summary: CPAP treatment appears to mitigate and slow cognitive decline in OSA patients, particularly in attention, vigilance, and information processing speed, and may reduce dementia risk. Larger controlled studies are needed to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Older patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the impact of CPAP on chest anatomy and tumor motion in patients receiving radiation therapy, assessing its potential to reduce lung and heart toxicity.
results_summary: CPAP significantly increased lung volume by 37% and demonstrated volumetric and dosimetric benefits compared to free breathing (FB). It was well tolerated by most patients, with only 3 withdrawing due to discomfort.
population_specificity: Patients with primary or secondary lung tumors, left-sided breast cancer, or liver metastases referred for radiation therapy.
effective_dosage: Maximal pressure of 15 cm H₂O via face mask.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare leakage between two neonatal CPAP interfaces (prongs and nasal mask) and evaluate the effectiveness of leak-corrective manoeuvres.
results_summary: Prongs showed significantly lower leakage compared to nasal masks, and leak-corrective manoeuvres reduced leakage for both interfaces. Large leakages were common but less pronounced with prongs.
population_specificity: Newborn infants with CPAP, stable spontaneous breathing, low oxygen requirement, postmenstrual age over 28 weeks, and no comorbidities (n=50).
study_duration: Data collected between August 2018 and October 2019 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: To determine the effect of CPAP on gait control in severe obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) patients.
results_summary: The study assessed gait parameters under single and dual-task conditions before and after an 8-week CPAP intervention, with stride-time variability as the primary endpoint. Secondary outcomes included changes in gait control determinants.
population_specificity: 24 severe OSAS patients (median age 59.5 years, 87.5% male, BMI 28.2 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of non-invasive respiratory support, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure, in clinical conditions, particularly focusing on challenges and innovations in low- and middle-income countries.
results_summary: The study found that non-invasive respiratory support reduces the need for invasive mechanical ventilation, lowers the risk of nosocomial pneumonia, and decreases mortality in selected pediatric and adult populations. However, most studies are from high-income countries, highlighting a gap in data and resources for low- and middle-income countries.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult populations, particularly in low- and middle-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the characteristics and management of respiratory failure in moderate-to-late preterm infants, focusing on the use of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP).
results_summary: The study found that CPAP was widely used in the delivery room, with 88.5% of infants in group 1 and 82.9% in group 2 receiving it. The incidence of respiratory and/or hemodynamic complications was low (8.6%), suggesting CPAP was effective in managing respiratory failure.
population_specificity: Moderate-to-late preterm infants (30+ weeks gestation) in neonatal intensive care units.
study_duration: Median hospitalization duration was 36 days for group 1 and 15 days for group 2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of orofacial myofunctional therapy (OMT) in treating OSA, including its potential to improve CPAP adherence and address residual OSA.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that CPAP may not always be effective in mild to moderate OSA, especially with non-anatomical traits, but OMT can improve outcomes like snoring, apnea-hypopnea index, and sleep quality. OMT also aids CPAP adherence and prevents residual OSA in children post-adenotonsillectomy.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult OSA patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the funding policies of clinical commissioning groups in England for the treatment of obstructive sleep apnoea, focusing on the availability of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) and other treatment modalities.
results_summary: Most clinical commissioning groups (49 of 60) funded CPAP based on clinical assessment or criteria aligned with national guidelines, while 11 offered no policy. Other treatments like mandibular advancement devices and surgeries were less consistently funded, leaving CPAP-intolerant patients with limited options in some regions.
population_specificity: Clinical commissioning groups in England (60 out of 190 sampled).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CPAP treatment on fatigue, sleep quality, somnolence, pain, disability, and quality of life in MS patients with OSAH.
results_summary: CPAP did not significantly improve the primary outcome (FSS) at 6 months but showed a trend toward improved FSS and a significant reduction in somnolence at 3 months.
population_specificity: MS patients with fatigue, poor subjective sleep quality, and OSAH (apnea-hypopnea index ≥15 events/hour) but without severe OSAH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prohormone levels (copeptin, proANP, proADM) could serve as diagnostic markers for OSA and indicators of response to CPAP therapy.
results_summary: Copeptin levels were significantly higher in OSA patients at baseline. ProADM levels changed significantly after 1 and 6 months of CPAP therapy, while proANP levels decreased after 12 hours of CPAP, suggesting acute and long-term response markers.
population_specificity: 310 patients with suspected OSA (232 diagnosed with OSA, 30 without OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of noninvasive respiratory support, particularly Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP), in reducing lung injury and bronchopulmonary dysplasia in extremely preterm infants.
results_summary: The study highlights that CPAP has replaced invasive mechanical ventilation for initial stabilization and treatment of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants, but questions remain about its indiscriminate use and the need for better identification of infants suited for noninvasive support.
population_specificity: Extremely preterm infants, particularly those at high risk of lung injury and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence on the perioperative use of CPAP therapy, particularly its effects on postoperative outcomes in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP after surgery improves oxygenation, reduces reintubation and mechanical ventilation needs, and decreases apnea/hypopnea frequency and related hypoxemia. However, poor adherence and limited high-quality studies hinder definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Surgical patients with known or suspected obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in treating central sleep apnea (CSA) induced by chronic opioid use.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP is less effective than adaptive servo-ventilation (ASV) in reducing CSA events in chronic opioid users, but no major clinical consequences of CSA were identified. The abstract suggests CSA might be a compensatory mechanism, raising questions about the benefits of treatment.
population_specificity: Chronic opioid users with central sleep apnea (CSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy on the recurrence or progression of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP therapy reduced the risk of AF recurrence or progression by 63% compared to non-users, with recurrence rates similar to those in non-OSA patients. The analysis included nine studies with 14,812 patients and showed statistically significant benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and atrial fibrillation (AF).

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the effects of insulin detemir versus neutral protamine Hagedorn on neonatal and maternal outcomes in women with type 2 or overt type 2 diabetes mellitus, with respiratory distress (including the need for continuous positive airway pressure) as one component of the primary outcome.
results_summary: The study found that insulin detemir had an 87% probability of reducing adverse neonatal outcomes (including respiratory distress requiring continuous positive airway pressure) compared to neutral protamine Hagedorn. Secondary outcomes also favored insulin detemir, with lower rates of maternal hypoglycemic events and hypertensive disorders.
population_specificity: Women with singleton gestation and type 2 or overt type 2 diabetes mellitus seeking obstetrical care at ≤21 weeks' gestation.
effective_dosage: Not specified for continuous positive airway pressure (study focused on insulin regimens).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated (study period was September 2018 to January 2020).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of CPAP on ambulatory blood pressure and subclinical myocardial injury in subjects with obstructive sleep apnea and hypertension.
results_summary: Short-term CPAP treatment improved ambulatory blood pressure and alleviated subclinical myocardial injury and strain in subjects with OSA and difficult-to-control hypertension.
population_specificity: Subjects with hypertension requiring at least three antihypertensive medications and moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea (75% male, mean age 51±8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and compare clinical treatments and research activities for OSA, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure, to guide patients and physicians in selecting suitable treatments.
results_summary: The study reviewed various OSA treatments, including CPAP, analyzing their methodologies, success rates, and economic burdens, but did not provide specific efficacy data for CPAP alone. It highlighted the need for multidisciplinary management and future research on emerging treatments like hypoglossal nerve stimulation.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining a weight-loss Mediterranean diet/lifestyle intervention with CPAP could improve inflammation and oxidative stress markers more effectively than CPAP alone in patients with OSA.
results_summary: The study found that combining CPAP with a Mediterranean diet/lifestyle intervention led to greater reductions in inflammation (lower CRP levels) and oxidative stress (lower urinary 8-iso prostaglandin F2a levels) compared to CPAP alone. No changes were observed in adiponectin or oxidized guanine levels across groups.
population_specificity: 187 overweight adults with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The study does not evaluate Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP); it focuses on assessing the safety and efficacy of KB109, a synthetic glycan, in outpatients with mild to moderate COVID-19.
results_summary: The study does not report findings related to CPAP, as it investigates KB109's impact on gut microbiota, symptom duration, and health outcomes in COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: Adults ≥18 years with mild to moderate COVID-19, managed as outpatients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize findings on the cost-effectiveness of CPAP for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and assess strategies for organizing CPAP therapy.
results_summary: Most studies indicated CPAP is associated with better health outcomes but at higher costs, with incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICER) ranging widely. CPAP was found cost-effective after the second year for moderate-to-severe OSA, and organizing care in primary care settings improved cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), particularly moderate-to-severe cases.
study_duration: Varied across studies, with cost-effectiveness noted after the second year of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of prehospital CPAP versus usual care in reducing dyspnoea and respiratory rate in patients with severe acute respiratory distress.
results_summary: CPAP significantly reduced dyspnoea scores and respiratory rates compared to usual care, but it did not affect hospital length of stay.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥40 years with acute severe respiratory distress of non-traumatic origin unresponsive to initial EMS treatments.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated (study conducted from March 2016 to December 2018).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lung recruitment maneuvers (LRMs) on mortality and respiratory outcomes in mechanically ventilated neonates compared to routine care.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant difference between LRMs and routine care in mortality, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, duration of supplemental oxygen, or ventilatory support. Limited evidence suggested slight improvements in end-expiratory lung volume and mean arterial pressure with specific LRMs.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated neonates, including those with respiratory distress syndrome and other respiratory/non-respiratory causes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether non-benzodiazepine sedative hypnotics (NBSH) improve CPAP adherence in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that NBSH use was associated with increased CPAP adherence, including longer nightly use (0.62 hours more) and more nights of use (12.08% increase). Eszopiclone showed the most significant effect, while zolpidem and zaleplon require further investigation.
population_specificity: Patients newly diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the role of gender on clinical features and 28-day mortality in Covid-19 patients, not Continuous Positive Airway Pressure.
results_summary: The study found that hospitalized women were less likely to die from Covid-19 compared to men, but once severe disease occurred, the risk of dying was similar. The abstract does not mention Continuous Positive Airway Pressure.
population_specificity: 431 consecutive adult Covid-19 patients hospitalized in Bergamo, Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of two different nasal high-flow rates (8-10 L/min vs. 5-7 L/min) for primary respiratory support in preterm neonates with respiratory distress.
results_summary: Higher nasal flow rates (8-10 L/min) did not significantly reduce the need for higher respiratory support (CPAP/mechanical ventilation) or surfactant therapy compared to standard flow rates (5-7 L/min). However, standard flow rates (5 L/min) were found to be suboptimal for most preterm infants, requiring more frequent flow rate escalations.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates ≥28 weeks of gestation with respiratory distress from birth.
effective_dosage: Increased nasal flow therapy (8-10 L/min) vs. standard nasal flow therapy (5-7 L/min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term efficacy and self-reported outcomes of tongue-stabilizing device (TSD) therapy versus mandibular advancement device (MAD) therapy in adults with obstructive sleep apnea.
results_summary: Both TSD and MAD therapies showed significant improvements in respiratory event index and oxygen saturation, but MAD therapy was more effective for daytime sleepiness and quality-of-life improvements. TSD therapy had a low treatment acceptance rate (53.8%).
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bi-level noninvasive ventilation (NIV) modes, including nsNIPPV, SNIPPV, and BiPAP, versus NCPAP in reducing bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), mortality, and intubation/re-intubation rates in premature infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
results_summary: Both nsNIPPV and SNIPPV showed reduced re-intubation and BPD rates compared to NCPAP, with SNIPPV demonstrating stronger effects. nsNIPPV also reduced intubation rates, while BiPAP showed potential benefits in one study. No significant difference in mortality was observed.
population_specificity: Premature infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
effective_dosage: Pressure settings ≥ those used during mechanical ventilation for nsNIPPV and SNIPPV; BiPAP used two NCPAP levels ≤4 cm H2O apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review tools for personalizing the treatment of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm neonates, including the role of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) as a first-line treatment.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP is a first-line treatment for respiratory distress syndrome in preterm neonates, but current guidelines lack personalization. Advanced tools like lung ultrasound, surfactant assays, and oxygenation metrics show promise for individualized treatment, with lung ultrasound having the highest diagnostic accuracy.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates with respiratory distress syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a 12-week CPAP treatment on glycaemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes and newly detected obstructive sleep apnoea.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in glycaemic control metrics (average glucose levels, time in glucose range, hypoglycaemia, hyperglycaemia, or variability) after 12 weeks of CPAP treatment. HbA1c showed a minor decrease, but the clinical relevance was unclear.
population_specificity: 72 participants with type 2 diabetes and moderate to severe OSA (78% male, age 62 ± 7, AHI 35 ± 15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate effect of CPAP on exercise tolerance in children with severe therapy-resistant asthma (STRA).
results_summary: The study found that CPAP use before physical exercise increased exercise duration in children and adolescents with STRA, with improvements noted in peak expiratory flow (PEF) and forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1).
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 6 to 18 years old diagnosed with severe therapy-resistant asthma (STRA).
effective_dosage: CPAP with PEEP 10cmH2O (specific frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of recumbency on nasal resistance and airflow, particularly in relation to Continuous Positive Airway Pressure therapy discontinuation and compliance.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that recumbency significantly increases nasal resistance and reduces nasal airflow, which is particularly relevant for snorers and sleep apnea patients. The study included nine studies with 291 individuals, showing a statistically significant difference in nasal airway resistance.
population_specificity: Snorers and sleep apnea patients (291 individuals across nine studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether short-term daytime CPAP application before the titration night improves polysomnographic data and CPAP adherence in patients with moderate to severe OSA.
results_summary: Daytime CPAP application led to significantly higher total sleep time, sleep efficiency, and time in stage N3 during the titration night, as well as better CPAP adherence at one-month follow-up compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) recommended for CPAP titration.
effective_dosage: CPAP applied for 30-60 minutes during daytime before titration night.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in managing hypoxaemic respiratory failure in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The panel made a conditional recommendation for the use of CPAP in patients with hypoxaemic respiratory failure, indicating moderate efficacy but not strong enough for a definitive recommendation. The evidence supported its use alongside other interventions like high-flow nasal oxygen.
population_specificity: Hospitalised COVID-19 patients with hypoxaemic respiratory failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether telemedicine interventions improve adherence to Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy in patients with obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that telemedicine interventions significantly improved CPAP adherence compared to controls, with a pooled mean difference of 0.57 (95% CI = 0.33 to 0.80). The effect was observed over intervention periods ranging from 1 to 6 months.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and cardiovascular diseases and assess the potential role of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in reducing morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The study highlights that CPAP treatment for OSA is effective and suggests that screening and timely treatment could reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, though the link between OSA and cardiovascular diseases remains under-recognized.
population_specificity: Individuals with obstructive sleep apnea, particularly those with associated cardiovascular conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether CPAP therapy for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) affects hypertension (HT).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but indicates that CPAP is the most common treatment for OSA, which may counteract apnea or hypopnea, and the review focuses on its potential impact on HT.
population_specificity: Individuals with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and hypertension (HT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the existing literature on perioperative non-invasive respiratory support, including CPAP, to assess its roles and outcomes in pre-, intra-, and postoperative settings.
results_summary: CPAP was associated with improved ventilatory variables and reduced postoperative respiratory complications preoperatively, but intraoperative data were scarce. Postoperatively, CPAP improved arterial blood gases and reduced reintubation rates, though no differences were found in mortality or other complications.
population_specificity: Perioperative patients, with specific subgroups noted (e.g., obesity, pregnancy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of pitolisant versus placebo for excessive daytime sleepiness in narcolepsy and OSA, including its effects on patients without continuous positive airway pressure therapy.
results_summary: Pitolisant significantly reduced excessive daytime sleepiness (ESS), increased mean sleep latency, and improved quality of life (EQ-5D) compared to placebo, with a higher risk of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), primarily insomnia. OSA patients benefited more, especially those not using continuous positive airway pressure therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with narcolepsy and Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of high-flow nasal cannulae (HFNC) compared to standard oxygen therapy or non-invasive ventilation (NIV/NIPPV, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) for respiratory support in adults in the ICU.
results_summary: HFNC may reduce treatment failure compared to standard oxygen therapy but shows little to no difference in mortality, pneumonia cases, or ICU stay length. Compared to NIV/NIPPV, HFNC likely has minimal impact on treatment failure, with most outcomes showing no significant difference, though evidence certainty was often low.
population_specificity: Adults admitted to the ICU, including post-extubation and non-mechanically ventilated patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) on blood pressure and cardiovascular outcomes in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and hypertension.
results_summary: CPAP showed modest effects on blood pressure but did not reduce cardiovascular event rates in nonsleepy OSA patients. Combination strategies, including antihypertensive agents and renal denervation, may be needed for better outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the budget impact and resource consumption of early rescue surfactant therapy (LISA) versus CPAP alone in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: Early rescue with LISA reduced resource consumption and costs compared to CPAP alone, particularly for infants born at 25-28 weeks gestation, with higher savings and a 97.4% probability of being cost-saving. The reduction in bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) incidence with LISA was a key factor influencing the budget impact.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born at 25-32 weeks gestation with respiratory distress syndrome and fraction of inspired oxygen ≥0.3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and compliance of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found poor CPAP compliance (median 49.3% of days with use) despite improvements in OSA severity post-bariatric surgery. CPAP effectiveness was not directly measured, but OSA parameters improved significantly after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with OSA undergoing bariatric surgery (median age 49.5 years, 68.2% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness of helmet CPAP as a treatment, bridge to intubation, or rescue therapy for COVID-19 pneumonia patients with respiratory failure, including those with care limitations (DNI).
results_summary: Helmet CPAP was successful in 69% of full-treatment patients and 28% of DNI patients, improving oxygenation without requiring intubation in most cases. It was feasible for several days outside the ICU despite persistent gas exchange impairment.
population_specificity: COVID-19 pneumonia patients with respiratory failure failing standard oxygen therapy, including those with do-not-intubate (DNI) orders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of CPAP treatment on cognitive deterioration in patients with obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or Alzheimer's disease dementia (ADD).
results_summary: The study found that CPAP adherence was associated with a lower mean change in cognitive deterioration (measured by CDR) compared to non-adherent patients, though no significant differences were observed in MMSE scores. Overall, cognitive scores declined over time in the entire group.
population_specificity: Patients with MCI or ADD and comorbid OSAS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathophysiology, clinical evaluation, and management of excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
results_summary: CPAP therapy reduces EDS in many OSA patients, but a significant proportion continue to experience residual EDS despite optimized treatment. Wake-promoting pharmacotherapy (e.g., modafinil, solriamfetol) has shown efficacy in reducing residual EDS and improving quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) experiencing excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review conventional and emerging treatment options, including cryotherapy, for conjunctival melanoma.
results_summary: The abstract mentions cryotherapy as one of the mainstays of treatment for conjunctival melanoma but does not provide specific findings on its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with conjunctival melanoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the management options for twelfth rib syndrome, including the efficacy of cryotherapy for pain relief.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was described as having some success in treating twelfth rib syndrome, but the evidence is limited and lacks long-term efficacy data. Surgical rib resection and nerve blocks were also noted as potential treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with twelfth rib syndrome experiencing chronic chest, back, flank, or abdominal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of low-dose oral isotretinoin as adjuvant treatment for anogenital warts when combined with cryotherapy.
results_summary: Both cryotherapy alone and combined with isotretinoin showed 50% clearance of warts, with no significant difference in recurrence rates. Quality of life improved in both groups, and no serious adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Hispanic patients with anogenital warts.
study_duration: 6 weeks of treatment, followed by 4 months of follow-up.
